DOC.HEAD: Tass Gives Details on Romanian Protests, No Defense of Ceausescu
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The official Tass news agency dispatched dramatic and detailed reports from Romania's capital early Friday, making little attempt to hide the swelling public feelings against President Nicolae Ceausescu. Absent from the Tass reports were any details of Ceausescu's speech at an official rally in Bucharest, where he was shouted down. In years past, Tass would have emphasized Ceausescu's views. Instead, it reported the growing protests against him and clashes between demonstrators and police. The coverage highlighted the Kremlin's changing attitude toward the conservative Communist stalwart, which has resulted in frosty meetings between Ceausescu and reform-minded Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev repeatedly has expressed support for the reformers who have taken power this year in other Eastern European countries. The Soviet president withheld comment on the events in Romania, where hundreds, perhaps thousands, have been reported killed in recent days. He told the Soviet parliament that members from the republic of Moldavia had called for adoption of a statement on the turmoil in the country on their eastern border. But Gorbachev said the Soviet Union had not received enough information about the events to warrant comment, even though the Foreign Ministry summoned the Romanian ambassador in Moscow and asked its envoy in Bucharest to supply details. ``The Romanian ambassador here does not provide an opportunity to form a notion of what is taking place in that country,'' Gorbachev told the 2,250 deputies. Tass, meanwhile, spoke of swelling numbers of demonstrators shouting anti-Ceausescu slogans. It said the government responded with tanks patrolling the streets, and ``There is yet no official response to the events in Bucharest.'' Tass also reported that at least two people were killed after they were run over by an armored personnel carrier and that demonstrators were fired on. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev, at a Moscow briefing, declined comment. ``If we do receive information on victims among people we of course will be extremely sorry for them,'' he said. But he added: ``We should emphasize that we do have opinions on what is happening but in my place as an official representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs I cannot go into comments without having all-inclusive information and orders in that regard.'' The Kremlin's attitude toward the Romanian leader became apparent Dec. 4 after Ceausescu met Gorbachev in Moscow. An official report said the two met in ``comradely fashion in the spirit of an open exchange of opinions.'' In diplomatic jargon, that means they disagreed sharply. In the Soviet republic of Moldavia, which borders Romania and has a large populace that speak a Romanian dialect, activists said they planned an outdoor religious service Friday for victims of the bloodshed in Romania. Moldavians are ethnically very close to Romanians, but the border between their republic and Romania has been tightly guarded since Ceausescu refused in 1968 to take part in the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia. Natalya Pascal, a spokeswoman for the Moldavian People's Front, said ethnic Moldavians had not been able to gather any detailed information on the events across the border.
